handlers.name: Active Directory
handlers.description: Manage users, computers, groups, and other objects in Active Directory or another LDAP accessed directory service with these handlers.

handlerList.name: Active Directory Computer Add Groups
handlerList.description: Finds a user in active directory by Distinguished Name and adds the computer as a member to one or more groups.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler will use the server information and computer credentials configured in the task info values to authenticate and connect to the specified Active Directory server (using LDAP) and search for the computer based on the search parameters provided.  If a matching computer is found, it will be added as a member to each group specified in the groups parameter will be added to the computer. 



* If 'Distinguished Name' is selected, the 'distinguishedName' attribute will be used directly to retrieve the Computer entry. 

* If 'Full Name' is selected, the 'cn' attribute will be used to retrieve the Computer entry. 

* If 'Computer Name' is selected, the 'computerprincipalname' value will be used if the "Search Value" parameter includes an '@' sign (IE john.doe@domain.com) and the 'samaccountname' will be used if it does not (IE john.doe). 

* If 'Email Address' is selected, the 'mail' attribute will be used to retrieve the Computer entry. 

This handler will raise an Exception if the specified Computer or any of the specified Groups are not found in the Active Directory system. 


#### Important Note
This handler has been tested on Task 4.0.6 and should preform as expected on all Task 4.x.x versions.

parameters.Error Handling: Determine what to return if an error is encountered.
parameters.Search Value: The value of the Distinguished Name (Computer Name).
parameters.Groups: The common name(s) of the group(s) to add.  More than one group can be specified by separating each group with a comma.

results.Handler Error Message: Error message if an error was encountered and

2.description: * Added Never Drop Never Fail

handlerList.name: Active Directory Computer Remove Groups
handlerList.description: Finds a user in active directory by Distinguished Name (Computer Name) and adds the computer as a member to one or more groups.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler will use the server information and computer credentials configured in the task info values to authenticate and connect to the specified Active Directory server (using LDAP) and search for the computer based on the search parameters provided.  If a matching computer is found, it will be removed as a member from each group specified in the groups parameter will be added to the computer. 



* If 'Distinguished Name' is selected, the 'distinguishedName' attribute will be used directly to retrieve the User entry. 

* If 'Full Name' is selected, the 'cn' attribute will be used to retrieve the User entry. 

* If 'User Name' is selected, the 'computerprincipalname' value will be used if the "Search Value" parameter includes an '@' sign (IE john.doe@domain.com) and the 'samaccountname' will be used if it does not (IE john.doe). 

* If 'Email Address' is selected, the 'mail' attribute will be used to retrieve the User entry. 

This handler will raise an Exception if the specified User or any of the specified Groups are not found in the Active Directory system. 


#### Important Note
This handler has been tested on Task 4.0.6 and should preform as expected on all Task 4.x.x versions.

parameters.Error Handling: Determine what to return if an error is encountered.
parameters.Search By: 'Distinguished Name', 'Full Name', 'User Name', 'Computer Name', or 'Email Address'
parameters.Search Value: The value of the Distinguished Name (Computer Name).
parameters.Groups: The common name(s) of the group(s) to remove.  More than one group can be specified by separating each group with a comma.

handlerList.name: Active Directory Distribution List Member Retrieve
handlerList.description: Finds a Distribution List in active directory by Distinguished Name, or Email Address and returns a comma delimited list of immediate members (e-mail addresses)
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler will use the server information and user credentials configured in the task info values to authenticate and connect to the specified Active Directory server (using LDAP) and search for the distribution group on the search parameters provided.  If Email Address is the 'search by' parameter, the handler looks for a '@' symbol in the User Logon to determine how to search for the User Logon name.  A '@' symbol indicates a search for the LDAP attribute userPrincipalName (up to 100 characters) while the absence of the '@' symbol will result in a search for the LDAP attribute sAMAccountName (pre-Windows 2000). 



* If 'Distinguished Name' is selected, the 'distinguishedName' attribute will be used directly to retrieve the User objects that are a member of the provided group. 

* If 'Email Address' is selected, the Distinguished Name of the group will first be searched for by the mail address. 


#### Important Note
This handler has been tested on Task 4.0.6 and should preform as expected on all Task 4.x.x versions.

parameters.Error Handling: Determine what to return if an error is encountered.
parameters.Search By: Choose which attribute of the user to search by
parameters.Search Value: The actual search expression to search for

results.Handler Error Message: Error message if an error was encountered and
results.Email Addresses: The email addresses of all users in the group.

handlerList.name: Active Directory Group Create
handlerList.description: Creates an Active Directory group entry and uses the provided parameter values to specify common attributes.  This handler will fail if the group already exists.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler will use the server information and user credentials configured in the task info values to authenticate and connect to the specified Active Directory server (using LDAP) and create a group entry. 

In order to build up the Distinguished Name (a unique identifier for the active directory user entry), the handler uses a template specified as a task info value. 

The following entry attributes are set once the user entry is created: 

* Direct Mappings 

  - name              => Group Name 

  - mail              => Email Address 

  - description       => Description 

  - info              => Notes 

* Computed Mappings 

  - grouptype         => Numerical representation of the group scope and type. 

* Special Attributes 

  - objectclass       => [top,group] 


#### Task Info Configuration

* *dn_format* - This value is used to specify the distinguished name of the Active Directory group entry to be created.  Anything within curly braces {} will be replaced with the value of the entry attribute or task info value associated with that key. For example, the default format is 'CN={displayname},CN=Users,{base}'.  In this case {displayname} is replaced with the displayname attribute value and {base} is replaced with the value of the 'base' task info value.  A full list of available entry attributes is available above.  If you use organizational units they can be substituted into the distinguished name in this manner. 


#### Important Note
This handler has been tested on Task 4.0.6 and should preform as expected on all Task 4.x.x versions.

parameters.Error Handling: Determine what to return if an error is encountered.
parameters.Group Name: The name of the group to be created
parameters.Description: The description of this group
parameters.Email Address: The Email Address for this group.  Active Directory can be configured so that all members of a group are notified when the group receives an Email.
parameters.Group Scope: Security groups or distribution groups are characterized by a scope that identifies how they are applied in the domain tree or forest. There are three group scopes: universal, global, and domain local.
parameters.Group Type: There are two group types, security and distribution.  Security groups allow you to manage user and computer access to shared resources.  Distribution groups are intended to be used solely as email distribution lists.

sampleConfiguration.Description: Allows access to the accounting resources

results.Handler Error Message: Error message if an error was encountered and

handlerList.name: Active Directory User Change Attribute
handlerList.description: Finds a user in active directory by Distinguished Name, Full Name, Email Address, or User Name and changes the specified LDAP attribute.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler will use the server information and user credentials configured in the task info values to authenticate and connect to the specified Active Directory server (using LDAP) and search for the user based on the search parameters provided.  If User Logon is the 'search by' parameter, the handler looks for a '@' symbol in the User Logon to determine how to search for the User Logon name.  A '@' symbol indicates a search for the LDAP attribute userPrincipalName (up to 100 characters) while the absence of the '@' symbol will result in a search for the LDAP attribute sAMAccountName (pre-Windows 2000). Finally, the handler changes the specified LDAP attribute to the new value. 



* If 'Distinguished Name' is selected, the 'distinguishedName' attribute will be used directly to retrieve the User entry. 

* If 'Full Name' is selected, the 'cn' attribute will be used to retrieve the User entry. 

* If 'User Name' is selected, the 'userprincipalname' value will be used if the "Search Value" parameter includes an '@' sign (IE john.doe@domain.com) and the 'samaccountname' will be used if it does not (IE john.doe). 

* If 'Email Address' is selected, the 'mail' attribute will be used to retrieve the User entry. 

This handler will fail if the user is not found, or if more than one result is found. 


#### Important Note
This handler has been tested on Task 4.0.6 and should preform as expected on all Task 4.x.x versions.

parameters.Error Handling: Determine what to return if an error is encountered.
parameters.Search By: Choose which attribute of the user to search by
parameters.Search Value: The actual search expression to search for
parameters.LDAP attribute: The LDAP attribute to change for the specified user
parameters.New attribute value: The new value the specified user will get for the LDAP Attribute parameter

results.Handler Error Message: Error message if an error was encountered and

handlerList.name: Active Directory User Create
handlerList.description: Creates an Active Directory user entry and uses the provided parameter values to specify common user attributes.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler will use the server information and user credentials configured in the task info values to authenticate and connect to the specified Active Directory server (using LDAP) and create a user entry. 

In order to build up the Distinguished Name (a unique identifier for the active directory user entry), the handler uses a template specified as a task info value. 

The following entry attributes are set once the user entry is created: 

* Direct Mappings 

  - givenname                     => First Name 

  - sn                            => Last Name 

  - displayname                   => Full Name 

  - description                   => Description 

  - physicaldeliveryofficename    => Office 

  - telephonenumber               => Telephone 

  - mail                          => Email 

  - title                         => Title 

  - department                    => Department 

  - company                       => Company 

* Computed Mappings 

  - userprincipalname => Is set the the "User Logon" parameter if it was provided using the User Principal Name format.  This attribute is not set if the "User Logon" parameter was provided without the "@domain" suffix. 

  - samaccountname    => Is set to the username portion of the "User Logon" parameter. 

  - initials          => A concatenated string of the capitalized first letters of each word in the "Full Name" parameter. 

* Special Attributes 

  - objectclass       => [top,person,organizationalPerson,user] 

If the node parameter "Activated" is set to 'Yes', the user will be activated immediately after the entry attributes have been set. 


#### Task Info Configuration

* *dn_format* - This value is used to specify the distinguished name of the Active Directory user entry to be created.  Anything within curly braces {} will be replaced with the value of the entry attribute or task info value associated with that key. For example, the default format is 'CN={displayname},CN=Users,{base}'.  In this case {displayname} is replaced with the displayname attribute value and {base} is replaced with the value of the 'base' task info value.  A full list of available entry attributes is available above.  If you use organizational units they can be substituted into the distinguished name in this manner. 


#### Important Note
This handler has been tested on Task 4.0.6 and should preform as expected on all Task 4.x.x versions.

parameters.Error Handling: Determine what to return if an error is encountered.
parameters.User Logon: The user's logon id.  This value should be specified as a User Principal Name (UPN) using the format 'username@domain.com'.  By convention, the User Logon is typically set to the same value as the user's email addresses.  In older Active Directory implementations, the domain may be omitted and the User Logon may be provided using the format 'username'.
parameters.First Name: The first name of the user.
parameters.Last Name: The last name of the user.
parameters.Full Name: The full name of the user.  In most Active Directory implementations, this value must be unique.
parameters.Description: The description of the user.  This value is displayed within the Active Directory user list and is often used to describe the role or purpose of a user account.
parameters.Office: A string representing the location of the user's office.  This could be a building name or number, floor, room or cube number, or any combination of values.
parameters.Telephone: The primary telephone number of the user.
parameters.Email: The email address of the user.
parameters.Title: The user's job title.
parameters.Department: The primary department that the user is a member of.
parameters.Company: The name of the company that the user is employed by.
parameters.Activated: Indicates whether or not the the user's account should be activated upon creation.

results.Handler Error Message: Error message if an error was encountered and
results.Distinguished Name: The distinguished name of the user entry that was created.

* Added Never Drop Never Fail

handlerList.name: Active Directory User Disable
handlerList.description: Finds a user in active directory by Distinguished Name, Full Name, Email Address, or User Name and disables the user's account.
handlerList.detailedDescription:

A '@' symbol indicates a search for the LDAP attribute userPrincipalName (up to 100 characters) while the absence of the '@' symbol will result in a search for the LDAP attribute sAMAccountName (pre-Windows 2000). Finally, the handler disables the account.

This handler will fail if the user is not found, or if more than one result is found. 


#### Important Note
This handler has been tested on Task 4.0.6 and should preform as expected on all Task 4.x.x versions.

handlerList.name: Active Directory User Expire Password
handlerList.description: Finds a user in active directory by Distinguished Name, Full Name, Email Address, or User Name and sets the password to expired, requiring the user to change it.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler will use the server information and user credentials configured in the task info values to authenticate and connect to the specified Active Directory server (using LDAP) and search for the user based on the search parameters provided.  If User Logon is the 'search by' parameter, the handler looks for a '@' symbol in the User Logon to determine how to search for the User Logon name.  A '@' symbol indicates a search for the LDAP attribute userPrincipalName (up to 100 characters) while the absence of the '@' symbol will result in a search for the LDAP attribute sAMAccountName(pre-Windows 2000). Finally, the handler will set the password to expired.  This is analogous to checking the box marked "User must change password at next logon" on the active directory users and computers administration tool. 



* If 'Distinguished Name' is selected, the 'distinguishedName' attribute will be used directly to retrieve the User entry. 

* If 'Full Name' is selected, the 'cn' attribute will be used to retrieve the User entry. 

* If 'User Name' is selected, the 'userprincipalname' value will be used if the "Search Value" parameter includes an '@' sign (IE john.doe@domain.com) and the 'samaccountname' will be used if it does not (IE john.doe). 

* If 'Email Address' is selected, the 'mail' attribute will be used to retrieve the User entry. 

This handler will fail if the user is not found, or if more than one result is found.

handlerList.description: Finds a user in active directory by Distinguished Name, Full Name, Email Address, or User Logon and remove that user as a member from one or more groups.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler will use the server information and user credentials configured in the task info values to authenticate and connect to the specified Active Directory server (using LDAP) and search for the user based on the search parameters provided. * If 'Distinguished Name' is selected, the 'distinguishedName' attribute will be used directly to retrieve the User entry. 

* If 'Full Name' is selected, the 'cn' attribute will be used to retrieve the User entry. 

* If 'User Name' is selected, the 'userprincipalname' value will be used if the "Search Value" parameter includes an '@' sign (IE john.doe@domain.com) and the 'samaccountname' will be used if it does not (IE john.doe). 

* If 'Email Address' is selected, the 'mail' attribute will be used to retrieve the User entry. 

This handler will raise an Exception if the specified User or any of the specified Groups are not found in the Active Directory system. 


#### Important Note
This handler has been tested on Task 4.0.6 and should preform as expected on all Task 4.x.x versions.

parameters.Error Handling: Determine what to return if an error is encountered.
parameters.Search By: Choose which attribute of the user to search by
parameters.Search Value: The value of the Distinguished Name, Full Name, User Logon, or Email Address that will be used to search for the desired user.
parameters.Groups: The common name(s) of the group(s) to remove.  More than one group can be specified by separating each group with a comma.

results.Handler Error Message: Error message if an error was encountered and

handlerList.name: Active Directory User Retrieve
handlerList.description: Finds a user in active directory by Distinguished Name, Full Name, Email Address, or User Name and returns a predefined set of attributes to include the Distinguished Name(dn).
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler will use the server information and user credentials configured in the task info values to authenticate and connect to the specified Active Directory server (using LDAP) and search for the user based on the search parameters provided.  If User Logon is the 'search by' parameter, the handler looks for a '@' symbol in the User Logon to determine how to search for the User Logon name.  A '@' symbol indicates a search for the LDAP attribute userPrincipalName (up to 100 characters) while the absence of the '@' symbol will result in a search for the LDAP attribute sAMAccountName (pre-Windows 2000). 



* If 'Distinguished Name' is selected, the 'distinguishedName' attribute will be used directly to retrieve the User entry. 

* If 'Full Name' is selected, the 'cn' attribute will be used to retrieve the User entry. 

* If 'User Name' is selected, the 'userprincipalname' value will be used if the "Search Value" parameter includes an '@' sign (IE john.doe@domain.com) and the 'samaccountname' will be used if it does not (IE john.doe). 

* If 'Email Address' is selected, the 'mail' attribute will be used to retrieve the User entry. 

This handler will fail if the user is not found, or if more than one result is found. 


#### Important Note
This handler has been tested on Task 4.0.6 and should preform as expected on all Task 4.x.x versions.

parameters.Error Handling: Determine what to return if an error is encountered.
parameters.Search By: Choose which attribute of the user to search by
parameters.Search Value: The actual search expression to search for

results.First Name: The first name of the user
results.Last Name: The last name of the user
results.Full Name: The full name of the user
results.Manager DN: The DN of the user's manager
results.Office: A string representing the location of the user's
results.Telephone: The primary telephone number of the user
results.Email Address: The email address of the user.
results.Account Enabled: True or False, whether the account is enabled.
results.Title: The user's job title.
results.Department: The primary department that the user is a member of
results.Company: The name of the company that the user is employed by

handlers.description: Amazon EC2 is one of the most popular infrastructure providers.

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Associate Route Table
handlerList.description: Associates a subnet with a route table.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
Associates a subnet with a route table. The subnet and route must be in the same VPC. This association causes traffic originating from the subnet to be routed according to the routes in the route table. A route can be associated with multiple subnets. For more information see the AWS Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Subnet ID: The ID of the subnet to which the route table will connect. Must match an existing value in AWS.
parameters.Route Table ID: The ID of the route table to connect to the subnet. Must match an existing value in AWS.

results.Association Id: The id of the association if the call was successful.

handlerList.description: Attaches an Internet gateway to a VPC, enabling connectivity between the Internet and the VPC.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
Attaches an Internet gateway to a VPC, enabling connectivity between the Internet and the VPC. For more information about your VPC and the Internet gateway, see the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Internet Gateway ID: The ID of the internet gateway. Must match an existing value in AWS.
parameters.VPC ID: The ID of the VPC. Must match an existing value in AWS.

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Authorize Security Group Ingress
handlerList.description: Add a security group ingress rule to a security group.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler uses the AWS REST API to Add a security group ingress rule to a security group. This handler implements a subset of the full AWS call (single rule submission only). Most of the inputs for this handler are conditionally required based on other input values. Source Security Group Name is required if a CIDR IP Address Name isn't specified and vice versa. Also, if a Source Security Group Name and/or Source Security Group Owner ID are provided, the IP Protocol, From Port, To Port, and CIDR IP Address Range must be left blank. This handler returns no results, so if no errors are caught and raised the rule has been successfully applied. 
More specific information about these parameters can be found in the Amazon EC2 Ruby documentation (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdkforruby/api/Aws/EC2/Client.html#authorize_security_group_ingress-instance_method) and in the EC2 REST documentation (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-properties-ec2-security-group-ingress.html). 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Group Name: The name of the security group. Normally used for the EC2-Classic or the default VPC security group.
parameters.Group ID: The ID of the security group. Required for a non-default VPC.
parameters.Source Security Group Name: The name of the source security group. For EC2-VPC, the source security group must be in the same VPC.
parameters.Source Security Group Owner ID: TThe AWS account number for the source security group. For EC2-VPC, the source security group must be in the same VPC. Creates rules that grant full ICMP, UDP, and TCP access. To create a rule with a specific IP protocol and port range, use a set of IP permissions instead.
parameters.IP Protocol: The IP protocol name (tcp, udp, icmp). (VPC only) Use -1 to specify all. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.
parameters.From Port: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number. For the ICMP type number, use -1 to specify all ICMP types. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.
parameters.To Port: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP code number. For the ICMP code number, use -1 to specify all ICMP codes for the ICMP type. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.
parameters.CIDR IP Address Range: The CIDR IP address range. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.

1.description: * Initial version. See README for details.

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. results.Tags: A list of tags (in JSON) that were attached to the internet gateway upon creation

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Create Key Pair As Attachment
handlerList.description: Creates a 2048-bit RSA key pair with the specified name and attaches the result to a Kinetic Request CE submission.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
Creates a 2048-bit RSA key pair with the specified name. Amazon EC2 stores the public key and displays the private key for you to save to a file. The returned private key is then uploaded to the configured Kinetic Filehub for the specified Kinetic Request CE instance (using the Request API to start that upload). Once the key has been uploaded to Filehub, the key pair will be attached to the specified field in a new Request CE submission. The Id for that created submission will be returned by the handler. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Key Name: A unique name for the key pair.
parameters.Space Slug: Slug of the space to create the submission in.
parameters.Kapp Slug: Slug of the kapp to create the submission in.
parameters.Form Slug: Slug of the form to create the submission in.
parameters.Field Name: Name of the field to upload the attachment to.

results.Submission Id: Id of submission if the call was successful.

1.description: * Initial version.  See README for details.

handlerList.changelogText:

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Create Key Pair
handlerList.description: Creates a 2048-bit RSA key pair with the specified name.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
Creates a 2048-bit RSA key pair with the specified name. Amazon EC2 stores the public key and displays the private key for you to save to a file. The private key is returned as an unencrypted PEM encoded PKCS#8 private key. If a key with the specified name already exists, Amazon EC2 returns an error. For more information about key pairs, see the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide online. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Key Name: A unique name for the key pair.

results.Name: Name of the successfully created key pair.
results.Fingerprint: Fingerprint of the successfully created key pair.
results.Material: The full contents of the created private key.

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Create Network Interface
handlerList.description: Creates a network interface in the specified subnet. For more information see the Amazon Elastic Cloud Compute User Guide online.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
Creates a network interface in the specified subnet. For more information see the Amazon Elastic Cloud Compute User Guide online. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Subnet ID: The ID of the subnet to associate with the network interface.
parameters.Description: A description for the network interface.
parameters.Private IP Address (Primary): The primary private IP address of the network interface. If you don't specify an IP address, Amazon EC2 selects one for you from the subnet range. If you specify an IP address, you cannot indicate any IP addresses specified in Private IP Addresses as primary (only one IP address can be designated as primary).
parameters.Security Group IDs: The IDs of one or more security groups, separated by commas.
parameters.Private IP Addresses: One or more private IP addresses in JSON format. Note: only one IP address can be designated as primary, and if you are using the 'Private IP Address (Primary)' as well as this field, that will be the primary -- [{"private_ip_address":"IP address","primary":true},{"private_ip_address":"IP address","primary":false}]
parameters.Secondary Private IP Address Count: The number of secondary private IP addresses to assign to a network interface. When you specify a number of secondary IP addresses, Amazon EC2 selects these IP addresses within the subnet range. You can't specify this option and specify more than one private IP address using Private IP Addresses

results.Network Interface Id: The Id of the network interface
results.Owner Id: The AWS account Id of the owner of the network interface
results.Requester Id: The ID of the entity that launched the instance on your behalf (for example, AWS Management Console or Auto Scaling).
results.Requester Managed: A boolean indicating whether the network interface is being managed by AWS
results.Status: The status of the network interface
results.Private IP Address: The IPv4 address of the network interface within the subnet
results.Source Dest Check: A boolean indicating whether traffic to or from the instance is validated
results.Groups: A list of security groups for the network interface
results.Attachment Attachment Id: The Id of the network interface attachment
results.Attachment Instance Owner Id: The AWS account Id of the owner of the instance
results.Attachment Device Index: The device index of the network interface attachment on the instance
results.Attachment Attach Time: The timestamp indicating when the attachment initiated
results.Attachment Delete On Termination: A boolean indicating whether the network interface is deleted when the instance is terminated
results.Association Public IP: The address of the Elastic IP address bound to the network interface
results.Association IP Owner Id: The Id of the Elastic IP address owner
results.Tag Set: Any tags assigned to the network interface
results.Private IP Addresses: A list of private IPv4 addresses associated with the network interface

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Create Subnet
handlerList.description: Creates a subnet in an existing VPC.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
Creates a subnet in an existing VPC. For more information see the AWS Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.VPC Id: The ID of the VPN in which the subnet will be created. Must match an existing value in AWS.
parameters.CIDR Block: The network range for the subnet, in CIDR notation. For example: 10.0.0.0/24. After a subnet is created, the CIDR block cannot be changed. The subnet's CIDR Block can be the same as the VPC's CIDR block, or a subset of the VPC's CIDR block. If you create more than one subnet in a VPC, the subnets' CIDR blocks must not overlap. The smallest subnet you can create uses a /28 netmask (16 IP addresses), and the largest uses a /16 netmask (65,536 IP addresses).
parameters.Availability Zone: The availability zone for the subnet.

results.Subnet State: The current state of the subnet
results.Subnet VPC Id: The ID of the VPC the subnet is in

results.Subnet Map Public IP on Launch: A boolean indicating whether instances launched in this subnet receive a public IPv4 address

This handler uses the AWS REST API. Creates a single tag against a single resource. Will overwrite an existing tag with the same key.  Note: Per AWS, each resource can have a maximum of 10 tags. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Resource: This tag will be applied to the resource id provided here.
parameters.Key: The key value for this tag. If an existing tag exists with this key it will be overwritten.
parameters.Value: The value for the tag. A blank value in this field will result in an empty value for this tag.

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Create VPC
handlerList.description: Creates a VPC
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler uses the AWS REST API to create a VPC for AWS. The input takes a CIDR and an Instance Tenancy options as input values. For Instance Tenancy, a value of 'default' means that instances can be launched with any tenancy; a value of 'dedicated' means all instances launched into the VPC are launched as dedicated tenancy instances regardless of the tenancy assigned to the instance at launch. Dedicated tenancy instances run on single-tenant hardware. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.CIDR Block: The network range for the VPC, in CIDR notation.
parameters.Instance Tenancy: The supported tenancy options for instances launched into the VPC are default, dedicated, or host.

results.VPC State: The current state of the VPC
results.VPC CIDR Block: The primary IPv4 CIDR block for the VPC
results.VPC DHCP Options ID: The ID of the set of DHCP options you've associated with the VPC (or default if the default options are associated with the VPC)
results.VPC Tags: Any tags assigned to the VPC
results.VPC Instance Tenancy: The allowed tenancy of instances launched into the VPC
results.VPC Is Default: Indicates whether the VPC is the default VPC

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Delete Route Table
handlerList.description: Deletes a specified route table.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler deletes an associate subnet with a route table. The subnet and route must be in the same VPC. You must disassociate the route table from any subnets before you can delete it.  You cannot delete the main route table. This association causes traffic originating from the subnet to be routed according to the routes in the route table. A route can be associated with multiple subnets. For more information see the AWS Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Route Table ID: The ID of the route table to delete.

The available details are currently 'zone_name','state','region_name', and 'messages'.

results.Availability Zone Names: A comma separated list of availability zone names that were returned
results.Availability Zone Details: A JSON object containing the availability zone details in the form of {"zone1": {"name": "zone1","region_name"...}, "zone2": ...}

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Image List
handlerList.description: Retrieves list of machine images attached to the AWS credentials supplied
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler will be used primarily in a loop to iterate over multiple EC2 image instances. In order to be used by the Loop handler, a single value is returned as an escaped XML string. called "Instance List". 
The Instance List will have the following format: <images> <image>ari-fe916297</image> <image>ari-8b779ae2</image> <image>ari-926b8bfb<image> </instances> 
To setup the Loop handler, refer to the Image List from this handler for 'Data Source' and use '/images/image'as the 'Variable Path'. 
The describe_images function is the base AWS::EC2 gem call we are using for this handler and returns a multi-level hash/array nest with a top level hash key of "imagesSet". 
The imagesSet has the following pseudo-xml form. Elements with the <item> tag are array members and are referenced by numerical index. 
All others are hash members and are references by element/key name. 
<imagesSet> <item> <imageId/> <imageLocation/> <imageState/> <imageOwnerId/> <isPublic/> <architecture/> <imageType/> <kernelId/> <ramdiskId/> <imageOwnerAlias/> <name/> <description/> <rootDeviceType/> <rootDeviceName/> <blockDeviceMapping> <item> <deviceName/> <ebs> <snapshotId/> <volumeSize/> <deleteOnTermination/> </ebs> </item> </blockDeviceMapping> <virtualizationType/> <tagSet/> <hypervisor/> </item> </imagesSet> 
To retrieve the imageId, for example, simply flatten the above structure by removing inapplicable items 
<imagesSet> <item> <imageId/> </item> </imagesSet> 
Treat items as arrays and all other members as hash keys. Doing so, we can reference imageId value in the following manner: 
@base_aws_object.imagesSet.item[index].imageId

parameters.Image Launch Permissions: Indicate whether you want public images, private images or both returned
parameters.Image Architecture: Indicate whether you want public images, private images or both returned
parameters.Image Type: Indicate whether you want public images, private images or both returned
parameters.Image State: Indicate whether you want public images, private images or both returned

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Image Retrieve
handlerList.description: Retrieves the properties of the image supplied
handlerList.detailedDescription:
The describe_images function is the base AWS::EC2 gem call we are using for this handler and returns a multi-level hash/array nest with a top level hash key of "imagesSet". 
The imagesSet has the following pseudo-xml form. Elements with the <item> tag are array members and are referenced by numerical index. 
All others are hash members and are references by element/key name. 
<imagesSet> <item> <imageId/> <imageLocation/> <imageState/> <imageOwnerId/> <isPublic/> <architecture/> <imageType/> <kernelId/> <ramdiskId/> <imageOwnerAlias/> <name/> <description/> <rootDeviceType/> <rootDeviceName/> <blockDeviceMapping> <item> <deviceName/> <ebs> <snapshotId/> <volumeSize/> <deleteOnTermination/> </ebs> </item> </blockDeviceMapping> <virtualizationType/> <tagSet/> <hypervisor/> </item> </imagesSet> 
To retrieve the imageId, for example, simply flatten the above structure by removing inapplicable items 
<imagesSet> <item> <imageId/> </item> </imagesSet> 
Treat items as arrays and all other members as hash keys. Doing so, we can reference imageId value in the following manner: 
@base_aws_object.imagesSet.item[index].imageId 
In this handler, we are returning just the more interesting properties for an instance. Future versions may incorporate additional properties.

parameters.Image ID: The image id of the EC2 image that this handler will retrieve details about

results.Image State: Current state of the AMI. If the operation returns available, the image is successfully registered and available for launching.
results.Owner Id: AWS account ID of the image owner.
results.Image Type: The type of image (machine, kernel, or RAM disk).
results.Kernel Id: The kernel associated with the image, if any. Only applicable for machine images.
results.Image Owner Alias: The AWS account alias (e.g., amazon, self, etc.) or AWS account ID that owns the AMI.
results.Name: The name of the AMI that was provided during image creation.
results.Description: The description of the AMI that was provided during image creation.
results.Virtualization Type: The type of virtualization of the AMI.
results.Tag Set: Tags assigned to the resource. Each tag's information is wrapped in an item element.

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Instance List

handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler will be used primarily in a loop to iterate over multiple EC2 image instances. In order to be used by the Loop handler, a single value is returned as an escaped XML string. called "Instance List". 
The Instance List will have the following format: <instances> <instance>i-01234567</instance> <instance>i-abcdefgh</instance> <instance>i-0123abcd</instance> </instances> 
To setup the Loop handler, refer to the Instance List from this handler for 'Data Source' and use '/instances/instance'as the 'Variable Path'. 
The describe_instances function is the base AWS::EC2 gem call we are using for this handler and returns a multi-level hash/array nest with a top level hash key of "reservationsSet". 
The reservationSet has the following pseudo-xml form. Elements with the <item> tag are array members and are referenced by numerical index. 
All others are hash members and are references by element/key name. 
<reservationsSet> <reservationId/) <requesterId/>, <item> <groupSet> <item"> <groupId/> </item> </groupSet> <instancesSet> <item> <blockDeviceMapping> <item> <ebs> <attachTime/>, <status/>, <deleteOnTermination/>, <volumeId/>, <deviceName> </ebs> </item> <tagSet> <item> <value/> <key/> </item> </tagset>, <virtualizationType/>, <productCodes/> <ipAddress/>, <kernelId/> <amiLaunchIndex/> <clientToken/>, <privateIpAddress>, <keyName/>", <launchTime>, <instanceType/>, <imageId/>, <privateDnsName/>, <rootDeviceName/>, <rootDeviceType/> <monitoring/>", <reason/>, <placement/> <dnsName/>, <instanceId/>, <instanceState> <name/> <code/> </instanceState> </item> </instanceSet> </item> </reservationSet>, 
To retrieve the imageId, for example, simply flatten the above structure by removing inapplicable items 
<reservationsSet> <item> <instancesSet> <item> <imageId/>, </item> </instanceSet> </item> </reservationSet> 
Treat items as arrays and all other members as hash keys. Doing so, we can reference imageId value in the following manner:

The describe_instances function is the base AWS::EC2 gem call we are using for this handler and returns a multi-level hash/array nest with a top level hash key of "reservationsSet". 
The reservationSet has the following pseudo-xml form. Elements with the <item> tag are array members and are referenced by numerical index. 
All others are hash members and are references by element/key name. 
<reservationsSet> <reservationId/) <requesterId/>, <item> <groupSet> <item"> <groupId/> </item> </groupSet> <instancesSet> <item> <blockDeviceMapping> <item> <ebs> <attachTime/>, <status/>, <deleteOnTermination/>, <volumeId/>, <deviceName> </ebs> </item> <tagSet> <item> <value/> <key/> </item> </tagset>, <virtualizationType/>, <productCodes/> <ipAddress/>, <kernelId/> <amiLaunchIndex/> <clientToken/>, <privateIpAddress>, <keyName/>", <launchTime>, <instanceType/>, <imageId/>, <privateDnsName/>, <rootDeviceName/>, <rootDeviceType/> <monitoring/>", <reason/>, <placement/> <dnsName/>, <instanceId/>, <instanceState> <name/> <code/> </instanceState> </item> </instanceSet> </item> </reservationSet>, 
To retrieve the imageId, for example, simply flatten the above structure by removing inapplicable items 
<reservationsSet> <item> <instancesSet> <item> <imageId/>, </item> </instanceSet> </item> </reservationSet> 
Treat items as arrays and all other members as hash keys.  Doing so, we can reference imageId value in the following manner: 
@base_aws_object.reservationSet.item[index].instancesSet.item[index].imageId 
In this handler, we are returning just the more interesting properties for an instance. Future versions may incorporate additional properties.

parameters.Instance ID: The instance id of the EC2 virtual machine that this handler will retrieve details about.

results.Virtualization Type: The type of virtual machine for the instance.  Valid values are "hvm" or "paravirtual".
results.IP Address: The public IP address for the instance.
results.Kernel ID: The operating system associated with the instance's base image
results.AMI Launcher Index: The order in which the instance was launched within a launch group
results.Key Name: If the instance was launched with a key pair this is the name of the key
results.Launch Time: The timestamp of the last launch of the instance in the format: yyyy-mm-dd hh:mm tz
results.Instance Type: The architecture size of the instance
results.Image ID: The ID of the base AMI for the instance
results.Root Device Name: The internal storage path for the root device, for example "/dev/sda1"
results.Root Device Type: The type of root device.  Valid values are:  "ebs" - persistent storage, "instance-store" - storage allocated for just the duration of the running instance.
results.Architecture: CPU type for the instance.  Valid values are:  "i386" or "x86_64"
results.Monitoring State: Describes whether CloudWatch monitoring is attached to the instance.  Valid values are:  "enabled" or "disabled"
results.Availability Zone: Physical zone associated with the instance.  Used to isolate instances for HA.
results.Instance State: The state of the EC2 instance.

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Instance Stop
handlerList.description: This handler sends a stop request to an AWS EC2 machine instance
handlerList.detailedDescription:
The stop_instance function can be executed against any valid instance in any state. When executed against an already stopped instance, the Previous Status and Current Status will both be "stopped". 
The result of the stop_instance call is a mixed hash/array with the  following structure: 
<resultSet> <instancesSet> <item> <currentState> <name/> <code/> </currentState> <previousState> <name/> <code/> </previousState> <instanceId/> </item> </instancesSet> </resultsSet>

parameters.Instance ID: The instance id of the EC2 virtual machine that this handler will send a stop request to.

results.Previous Status: The state of the machine instance prior to the stop request being issued.
results.Current Status: The state of the machine instance after the stop request. The state will typically be "stopping".

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Modify Instance Attribute
handlerList.description: Modifies the specified attribute of the specified instance. You can specify only one attribute at a time.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler uses the AWS REST API to modify the specified attribute of the specified instance. You can specify only one attribute at a time.  For more information see the AWS Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Value: A new value for the attribute.
parameters.Block Device Mapping: Modifies the DeleteOnTermination attribute for volumes that are currently attached.
parameters.Source Destination Check: true or false. Specifies whether source/destination checking is enabled.
parameters.Disable API Termination: true or false. If the value is true, you can't terminate the instance using the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can.
parameters.Instance Type: The instance type. Changes the instance type to the specified value.
parameters.Kernel ID: Changes the instance's kernel to the specified value.
parameters.Ramdisk ID: Changes the instance's RAM disk to the specified value.
parameters.User Data: Changes the instance's user data to the specified value. Input is base64-encoded MIME data.
parameters.Security Group IDs: One or more security group names, separated by commas.
parameters.EBS Optimized: true or false.  Specifies whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O.
parameters.SRIOV Net Support: Set to simple to enable enhanced networking for the instance.

1.description: * Initial version.  See README for details.

AWS EC2 Modify Instance Attribute V1 (2017-08-24)

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Revoke Security Group Ingress
handlerList.description: Removes one or more ingress rules from a security group.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler uses the AWS REST API to Remove one or more ingress rules from a security group. The values that you specify in the revoke request (for example, ports) must match the existing rule's values for the rule to be removed. Each rule consists of the protocol and the CIDR range or source security group. For the TCP and UDP protocols, you must also specify the destination port or range of ports. For the ICMP protocol, you must also specify the ICMP type and code. Rule changes are propagated to instances within the security group as quickly as possible. However, a small delay might occur.  This handler implements a subset of the full AWS call (single rule submission only).  For more information see the AWS Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Group Name: The name of the security group.
parameters.Group ID: The ID of the security group. Required for a non-default VPC.
parameters.Source Security Group Name: The name of the source security group.
parameters.Source Security Owner ID: The AWS account ID for the source security group.
parameters.IP Protocol: The IP protocol name (tcp, udp, icmp). Use -1 to specify all.
parameters.From Port: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number.
parameters.To Port: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP code number.

1.description: * Initial version.  See README for details.

AWS EC2 Revoke Security Group Ingress V1 (2017-08-24)

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Run Instances
handlerList.description: Launches the specified number of instances using an AMI for which you have permissions.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler uses the AWS REST API Launch the specified number of instances using an AMI for which you have permissions.  For more information see the AWS Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 
The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Minimum Instance Count: The minimum number of instances to launch.
parameters.Maximum Instance Count: The maximum number of instances to launch.
parameters.Key Name: The name of the key pair.
parameters.Security Groups: One or more security group names, separated by commas.
parameters.Security Group IDs: One or more security group IDs, separated by commas.
parameters.User Data: The Base64-encoded MIME user data for the instances.
parameters.Ramdisk ID: The ID of the RAM disk.
parameters.Monitoring: true or false. The monitoring for the instance.
parameters.Subnet ID: The ID of the subnet to launch the instance into.
parameters.Disable API Termination: true or false. If you set this parameter to true, you can't terminate the instance using the Amazon EC2 console.
parameters.Instance Initiated Shutdown Behavior: Accepts 'stop' or 'terminate'.  Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown.
parameters.Client Token: Unique, case-sensitive identifier you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request.
parameters.EBS Optimized: true or false. Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O.

results.Reservation ID: Reservation of ID EC2 run instances.
results.Owner ID: Owner ID of EC2 run instances.
results.Requester ID: Requester ID of EC2 run instances.
results.Groups XLM: Groups XLM of EC2 run instances.
results.Groups String: Groups String of EC2 run instances.
results.Instances XML: Instances XML of EC2 run instances.
results.Instances String: Instances String of EC2 run instances.

handlers.name: Amazon S3
handlers.description: Amazon S3 'S3' stands for Simple Storage Service. This integration allows you to use S3 with very intricate yet compliant integration.

handlerList.name: Amazon S3 Expiring Url Generator
handlerList.description: Generate an expiring URL for S3.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler generates an expiring URL for S3. Expiring URLs take a bucket, a key (path + filename) and an expiration and build up a special URL that will give the user access to the file only for a certain time period. 


#### Authentication
This handler requires two info values for AWS authentication: Access Key ID and the Secret Access Key. These are analogous to username and password. 

To find authentication values from the AWS account: 



  1. Navigate to the following URL: https://aws.amazon.com/account/ 

  2. Click the "Security Credentials" link (if you are not logged in, you will be prompted to do so). 

  3. Click the "Access Credentials" link.  Here you will find a list of your Access Keys. 

  5. Use the Access Key ID to configure the access_key_id info value of this handler. 

  6. To retrieve the Secret Access Key, click the "Show" link next to the Access Key ID that will be used. 

  7. Use the Secret Access Key to configure the secret_access_key info value of this handler.

parameters.Region: Name of the region of the bucket (required if not specified as an info value).
parameters.Key: Name of the key in desired bucket (path + filename).
parameters.Seconds To Expire: Number of seconds in which URL will expire.  This may not exceed 604,800 seconds or one week.

results.Public Url: URL to desired bucket and key path for file.

1.description: * Initial version.  See README for details.

handlerList.changelogText:
Amazon S3 Expiring Url Generator V1 (2016-07-02)
* Initial version.  See README for details.

handlerList.detailedDescription: This handler creates and uploads content from an existing Request CE submission field value to an Amazon S3 bucket and then returns a public url of the successfully uploaded file. This is done by using an account's Access Key and Secret Access Key to authenticate with the Amazon S3 server and then uploading the file retrieved from Request CE and its content into the specified S3 bucket.

parameters.Region: Id of the region the inteded S3 server is located in (can also be configured as an info value).
parameters.Space Slug: Slug for the space the submission is in (can also be configured as an info value).
parameters.Bucket: Name of the bucket to upload to.
parameters.File Name: Name that will be given to the file on upload (if not provided, will default to the default filename stored in Request CE).
parameters.Submission Id: Submission Id that the attachment is located on.
parameters.Field Label: Field Label for the attachment field.

results.Public Url: A public url for the file that was just uploaded.

The handler first puts the data that was inputted into the JSON format and then posts that information using a REST call with basic auth. The handler first faciliates the upload through Remedy, then sends the file to Jira in a REST call, and then finishes by deleting the copy of the file from the specified Remedy server (since it the data will have already been sent to Jira). WARNING: Using this handler without enabling SSL will not be secure within a Jira project. Any errors that occur during the process will be caught and re-raised by this handler.

handlerList.name: Jira Issue Create
handlerList.description: This handler creates a new issue in a Jira project.
handlerList.detailedDescription: This handler uses the Jira Rest API library to create an issue within a Jira project. The handler first puts the data that was inputted into  JSON format and then posts that information using a REST call with basic auth. (WARNING: Using this handler without enabling SSL will not be secure). The id, key, and url of the issue will be returned by the handler. Any errors that occur during the process will be caught and re-raised by this handler, or returned as an error message if specified.

parameters.Error Handling: Determine what to return if an error is encountered.
parameters.Project Key: The Key of the project that the issue will be added to.
parameters.Issue Type: The name of the issue type (ie. Bug, New Feature, Task, etc).
parameters.Description: An in-depth explanation of the issue.
parameters.Assignee: The username of the person you want to assign this issue to.
parameters.Priority: The name of the issue priority (ie. Major, Minor, Critical, etc).
parameters.Due Date: The due date of the issue in the form of YYYY-MM-DD.
parameters.Addtl Fields JSON: A JSON Map of Additional Fields to be included in the fields wrapper of the body.

results.Handler Error Message: Error message if an error was encountered and Error Handling is set to "Error Message".
results.id: The id of the issue that was created.
results.key: The key of the issue that was created.
results.url: The url of the issue that was created.

* Added Error Handling so the handler can return an error message vs throw an error

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Associate Route Table
handlerList.description: Associates a subnet with a route table.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
Associates a subnet with a route table. The subnet and route must be in the same VPC. This association causes traffic originating from the subnet to be routed according to the routes in the route table. A route can be associated with multiple subnets. For more information see the AWS Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Subnet ID: The ID of the subnet to which the route table will connect. Must match an existing value in AWS.
parameters.Route Table ID: The ID of the route table to connect to the subnet. Must match an existing value in AWS.

results.Association Id: The id of the association if the call was successful.

handlerList.detailedDescription:
Attaches an Internet gateway to a VPC, enabling connectivity between the Internet and the VPC. For more information about your VPC and the Internet gateway, see the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Internet Gateway ID: The ID of the internet gateway. Must match an existing value in AWS.
parameters.VPC ID: The ID of the VPC. Must match an existing value in AWS.

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Authorize Security Group Ingress
handlerList.description: Add a security group ingress rule to a security group.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler uses the AWS REST API to Add a security group ingress rule to a security group. This handler implements a subset of the full AWS call (single rule submission only). Most of the inputs for this handler are conditionally required based on other input values. Source Security Group Name is required if a CIDR IP Address Name isn't specified and vice versa. Also, if a Source Security Group Name and/or Source Security Group Owner ID are provided, the IP Protocol, From Port, To Port, and CIDR IP Address Range must be left blank. This handler returns no results, so if no errors are caught and raised the rule has been successfully applied. 

More specific information about these parameters can be found in the Amazon EC2 Ruby documentation (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdkforruby/api/Aws/EC2/Client.html#authorize_security_group_ingress-instance_method) and in the EC2 REST documentation (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-properties-ec2-security-group-ingress.html). 

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Group Name: The name of the security group. Normally used for the EC2-Classic or the default VPC security group.
parameters.Group ID: The ID of the security group. Required for a non-default VPC.
parameters.Source Security Group Name: The name of the source security group. For EC2-VPC, the source security group must be in the same VPC.
parameters.Source Security Group Owner ID: TThe AWS account number for the source security group. For EC2-VPC, the source security group must be in the same VPC. Creates rules that grant full ICMP, UDP, and TCP access. To create a rule with a specific IP protocol and port range, use a set of IP permissions instead.
parameters.IP Protocol: The IP protocol name (tcp, udp, icmp). (VPC only) Use -1 to specify all. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.
parameters.From Port: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number. For the ICMP type number, use -1 to specify all ICMP types. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.
parameters.To Port: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP code number. For the ICMP code number, use -1 to specify all ICMP codes for the ICMP type. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.
parameters.CIDR IP Address Range: The CIDR IP address range. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.

Creates an internet gateway and return the gateway's id, attachments, and tags. The list of returned attachments each include a 'vpc_id' and 'state' keys and the returned tags all contain a 'key' and 'value' keys. For more information see the AWS Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).

results.Id: The id of the internet gateway if the call was successful.
results.Attachments: A list of attachments (in JSON) that were attached to the internet gateway upon creation
results.Tags: A list of tags (in JSON) that were attached to the internet gateway upon creation

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Create Key Pair As Attachment
handlerList.description: Creates a 2048-bit RSA key pair with the specified name and attaches the result to a Kinetic Request CE submission.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
Creates a 2048-bit RSA key pair with the specified name. Amazon EC2 stores the public key and displays the private key for you to save to a file. The returned private key is then uploaded to the configured Kinetic Filehub for the specified Kinetic Request CE instance (using the Request API to start that upload). Once the key has been uploaded to Filehub, the key pair will be attached to the specified field in a new Request CE submission. The Id for that created submission will be returned by the handler. 

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Key Name: A unique name for the key pair.
parameters.Space Slug: Slug of the space to create the submission in.
parameters.Kapp Slug: Slug of the kapp to create the submission in.
parameters.Form Slug: Slug of the form to create the submission in.
parameters.Field Name: Name of the field to upload the attachment to.

results.Submission Id: Id of submission if the call was successful.

1.description: * Initial version.  See README for details.

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Create Key Pair
handlerList.description: Creates a 2048-bit RSA key pair with the specified name.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
Creates a 2048-bit RSA key pair with the specified name. Amazon EC2 stores the public key and displays the private key for you to save to a file. The private key is returned as an unencrypted PEM encoded PKCS#8 private key. If a key with the specified name already exists, Amazon EC2 returns an error. For more information about key pairs, see the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide online. 

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Key Name: A unique name for the key pair.

results.Name: Name of the successfully created key pair.
results.Fingerprint: Fingerprint of the successfully created key pair.
results.Material: The full contents of the created private key.

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Create Network Interface
handlerList.description: Creates a network interface in the specified subnet. For more information see the Amazon Elastic Cloud Compute User Guide online.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
Creates a network interface in the specified subnet. For more information see the Amazon Elastic Cloud Compute User Guide online. 

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Subnet ID: The ID of the subnet to associate with the network interface.
parameters.Description: A description for the network interface.
parameters.Private IP Address (Primary): The primary private IP address of the network interface. If you don't specify an IP address, Amazon EC2 selects one for you from the subnet range. If you specify an IP address, you cannot indicate any IP addresses specified in Private IP Addresses as primary (only one IP address can be designated as primary).
parameters.Security Group IDs: The IDs of one or more security groups, separated by commas.
parameters.Private IP Addresses: One or more private IP addresses in JSON format. Note: only one IP address can be designated as primary, and if you are using the 'Private IP Address (Primary)' as well as this field, that will be the primary -- [{"private_ip_address":"IP address","primary":true},{"private_ip_address":"IP address","primary":false}]
parameters.Secondary Private IP Address Count: The number of secondary private IP addresses to assign to a network interface. When you specify a number of secondary IP addresses, Amazon EC2 selects these IP addresses within the subnet range. You can't specify this option and specify more than one private IP address using Private IP Addresses

results.Network Interface Id: The Id of the network interface
results.Owner Id: The AWS account Id of the owner of the network interface
results.Requester Id: The ID of the entity that launched the instance on your behalf (for example, AWS Management Console or Auto Scaling).
results.Requester Managed: A boolean indicating whether the network interface is being managed by AWS
results.Status: The status of the network interface
results.Private IP Address: The IPv4 address of the network interface within the subnet
results.Source Dest Check: A boolean indicating whether traffic to or from the instance is validated
results.Groups: A list of security groups for the network interface
results.Attachment Attachment Id: The Id of the network interface attachment
results.Attachment Instance Owner Id: The AWS account Id of the owner of the instance
results.Attachment Device Index: The device index of the network interface attachment on the instance
results.Attachment Attach Time: The timestamp indicating when the attachment initiated
results.Attachment Delete On Termination: A boolean indicating whether the network interface is deleted when the instance is terminated
results.Association Public IP: The address of the Elastic IP address bound to the network interface
results.Association IP Owner Id: The Id of the Elastic IP address owner
results.Tag Set: Any tags assigned to the network interface
results.Private IP Addresses: A list of private IPv4 addresses associated with the network interface

parameters.Network Interface ID: The ID of a network interface.

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Create Subnet
handlerList.description: Creates a subnet in an existing VPC.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
Creates a subnet in an existing VPC. For more information see the AWS Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.VPC Id: The ID of the VPN in which the subnet will be created. Must match an existing value in AWS.
parameters.CIDR Block: The network range for the subnet, in CIDR notation. For example: 10.0.0.0/24. After a subnet is created, the CIDR block cannot be changed. The subnet's CIDR Block can be the same as the VPC's CIDR block, or a subset of the VPC's CIDR block. If you create more than one subnet in a VPC, the subnets' CIDR blocks must not overlap. The smallest subnet you can create uses a /28 netmask (16 IP addresses), and the largest uses a /16 netmask (65,536 IP addresses).
parameters.Availability Zone: The availability zone for the subnet.

results.Subnet State: The current state of the subnet
results.Subnet VPC Id: The ID of the VPC the subnet is in
results.Subnet CIDR Block: The IPv4 CIDR block assigned to the subnet
results.Subnet Available IP Address Count: The number of unused private IPv4 addresses in the subnet
results.Subnet Availability Zone: The Availability Zone of the subnet
results.Subnet Default for AZ: A boolean indicating whether this is the default subnet for the Availability Zone
results.Subnet Map Public IP on Launch: A boolean indicating whether instances launched in this subnet receive a public IPv4 address
results.Subnet Tags: Any tags assigned to the subnet

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Create VPC
handlerList.description: Creates a VPC
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler uses the AWS REST API to create a VPC for AWS. The input takes a CIDR and an Instance Tenancy options as input values. For Instance Tenancy, a value of 'default' means that instances can be launched with any tenancy; a value of 'dedicated' means all instances launched into the VPC are launched as dedicated tenancy instances regardless of the tenancy assigned to the instance at launch. Dedicated tenancy instances run on single-tenant hardware. 

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.CIDR Block: The network range for the VPC, in CIDR notation.
parameters.Instance Tenancy: The supported tenancy options for instances launched into the VPC are default, dedicated, or host.

results.VPC State: The current state of the VPC
results.VPC CIDR Block: The primary IPv4 CIDR block for the VPC
results.VPC DHCP Options ID: The ID of the set of DHCP options you've associated with the VPC (or default if the default options are associated with the VPC)
results.VPC Tags: Any tags assigned to the VPC
results.VPC Instance Tenancy: The allowed tenancy of instances launched into the VPC
results.VPC Is Default: Indicates whether the VPC is the default VPC

handlerList.name: AWS EC2 Delete Route Table
handlerList.description: Deletes a specified route table.
handlerList.detailedDescription:
This handler deletes an associate subnet with a route table. The subnet and route must be in the same VPC. You must disassociate the route table from any subnets before you can delete it.  You cannot delete the main route table. This association causes traffic originating from the subnet to be routed according to the routes in the route table. A route can be associated with multiple subnets. For more information see the AWS Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide online. 

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. Error response will be 'DryRunOperation' if the account has proper permissions and inputs; 'UnauthorizedOperation' if the account does not have proper permissions.

parameters.Dry Run: Dry run validates user permissions and inputs without completing the EC2 action (true or false).
parameters.Route Table ID: The ID of the route table to delete.

The Dry Run parameter validates user permissions and inputs. If it is set to true, an error will always be thrown by the handler before completing the handler action. parameters.Route Table ID: The ID of the affected route table.
parameters.Destination CIDR Block: The CIDR range for the route. The value you specify must match the CIDR for the route exactly.

handlerList.description: Returns a set of availability zones and details for each of those zones.
